And that could help save countless lives in two countries plagued by suicide bombings.
From the time kids start kindergarten until they walk out of the 12th grade, they are constantly being hit with quizzes, final exams, and standardized tests.
If they want to go on to college or grad school, more tests - tough ones, too, like the SAT and the GRE.
Many parents pay to have their kids prepped for the exams, but what if you don't have the cash?
Brothers Akil and Hakeem Bello say their test prep company, Bell Curves, can help.
So how does Bell Curves work differently from other test prep courses?
Well, I think the primary difference is in the focus which built the business model.
Our goal and our sort of philosophy is much more - well, I like to define our company as a self-sustaining philanthropy.
You know, we are a for-profit company, but simply for the purpose of being able to define our own mission, control our own finances, rather than a non-profit that has to answer to someone else.
So in terms of how we work with schools, we go in to create partnerships.

We look to create partnership with organizations, non-profits, community-based organizations to provide information and resources surrounding the process of moving from one level of education to the next.
Unlike, you know, the test prep industry as a whole, which is focused on gaining profit from seeking individuals who need to get to that level.
So the purpose and the focus and the mission is somewhat different than many of these organizations.
It sounds like what you're saying is that you want to lift many boats, not just one or two.

The goal is to provide information and resources up and down the pipeline: from the student who needs specific test preparation - how do I take the SAT, what are the things I need to know to do well on the SAT or the GMAT or the GRE or the LSAT - to the parent who needs to be able to guide the student to doing things at the right time in the right fashion across the board: to the administrators and educators who have enough on their plate dealing on a day-to-day basis with their part of educational process.

Now, to throw a standardized test into the mix to add another area that they may not have precise expertise, so we want to be able to take as much of that weight off the shoulders of other people as possible.
